Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, for the countries which are exporters of raw materials such as those in the region, the inflationary situation is more complex since the fall in the prices will tend to be accompanied by a depreciation of their currencies.\n                "}]

\\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: given the possible implications that less growth in the world economy could have for colombia’s economic growth, they advised waiting for new information before making a decision on benchmark interest rates.\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:04:15,591 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence advises waiting for new information before making a decision on benchmark interest rates, neither leaning towards raising or cutting rates."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{banrep}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Growth, Peso Value Change, Trade, BanRep Interest Rate, Energy, and Climate.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: How much inflation is present in the Colombian Economy, measured by CPI, and whether or not this value increases.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: The rate of unemployment in Colombia and its change over time.\n    \\item \\emph{Growth}: The rate of GDP growth in Colombia's economy, and any changes to its value.\n    \\item \\emph{Peso Value Change}: The appreciation, depreciation, or maintenance of the Colombian Peso.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: The amount of imports and exports going in, and any changes in the amounts and distribution of these goods.\n    \\item \\emph{BanRep Interest Rate}: The current interest rate set by the Central Bank of Colombia and any decisions surrounding it.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy}: The availability and price of energy in Colombia\n    \\item \\emph{Climate}: Notable climate conditions impacting Colombia, such as El Ni\\~no.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``They noted that the concern of a significant impact on food or power costs by the El Ni\\~no phenomenon has been waning.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Poor climate conditions like El Ni\\~no put inflationary pressures on agricultural and energy sectors. With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: inflation excluding food remained stable (2.9%).\n                "}]
2025-05-03 18:04:16,377 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence simply reports a stable inflation rate, which is close to the 3% target, without indicating any pressure to change interest rates."

Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the former is consistent with the 20% annual plunge in exports to venezuela.\n With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: likewise, if the trend that has been seen in prices for the main export products continues, the average terms of trade in 2013 will be lower than those seen last year and optionsthe board of directors took the following relevant aspects under consideration:(i) the growth of our With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: particularly, it is expected that in 2016 venezuela and brazil register contractions in their product again, while countries such as ecuador, chile, mexico and peru would continue exhibiting lower growth rateswith all the aforesaid, growth for colombia's major trading partners in 2015 would be lower than had been forecast a quarter ago.\n                "}]

With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in may, the annual variation of the ppi declined from 1.56% to 0.80%, and kept on declining since the fall commencing last october.\n                "}]

could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the figures available up to the first quarter of 2011 suggest growth will continue throughout the year, but at a more moderate pace.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{banrep}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Growth, Peso Value Change, Trade, BanRep Interest Rate, Energy, and Climate.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: How much inflation is present in the Colombian Economy, measured by CPI, and whether or not this value increases.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: The rate of unemployment in Colombia and its change over time.\n    \\item \\emph{Growth}: The rate of GDP growth in Colombia's economy, and any changes to its value.\n    \\item \\emph{Peso Value Change}: The appreciation, depreciation, or maintenance of the Colombian Peso.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: The amount of imports and exports going in, and any changes in the amounts and distribution of these goods.\n    \\item \\emph{BanRep Interest Rate}: The current interest rate set by the Central Bank of Colombia and any decisions surrounding it.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy}: The availability and price of energy in Colombia\n    \\item \\emph{Climate}: Notable climate conditions impacting Colombia, such as El Ni\\~no.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``They noted that the concern of a significant impact on food or power costs by the El Ni\\~no phenomenon has been waning.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Poor climate conditions like El Ni\\~no put inflationary pressures on agricultural and energy sectors. With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: for the year elapsed as of august, the cpi accumulated a 2.64% increase, this being a little higher than the one recorded in the same period of the previous year.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions a higher inflation rate compared to the previous year, which could lead to concerns about inflation exceeding the 3% target, indicating a hawkish stance."

With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{banrep}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Growth, Peso Value Change, Trade, BanRep Interest Rate, Energy, and Climate.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: How much inflation is present in the Colombian Economy, measured by CPI, and whether or not this value increases.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: The rate of unemployment in Colombia and its change over time.\n    \\item \\emph{Growth}: The rate of GDP growth in Colombia's economy, and any changes to its value.\n    \\item \\emph{Peso Value Change}: The appreciation, depreciation, or maintenance of the Colombian Peso.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: The amount of imports and exports going in, and any changes in the amounts and distribution of these goods.\n    \\item \\emph{BanRep Interest Rate}: The current interest rate set by the Central Bank of Colombia and any decisions surrounding it.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy}: The availability and price of energy in Colombia\n    \\item \\emph{Climate}: Notable climate conditions impacting Colombia, such as El Ni\\~no.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``They noted that the concern of a significant impact on food or power costs by the El Ni\\~no phenomenon has been waning.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Poor climate conditions like El Ni\\~no put inflationary pressures on agricultural and energy sectors. With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: (ii) in contrast, the strength of private (4%) and public (4.8%) consumption in the third quarter was similar to what had been seen in the second and a little better than had been expected.\n                "}]

With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: nevertheless, the gdp growth for the set of colombia’s commercial partners was maintained because price increases in some countries like ecuador were revised, given the recent trends.\n                "}]

With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in this scenario, it is essential for the monetary authority to continue monitoring the external conditions and the domestic effects of likely shocks.from the perspective of domestic demand, there was consensus in that uncertainty about the pace of economic recovery increased.\n                "}]

With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the gross loan portfolio in domestic currency continued to slow, registering an annual increase of 5.1% by november 6 compared to 7.3% the month before.\n                "}]

With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: others mentioned that the transmission of the reduction in the benchmark interest rate has not yet ended, therefore the assessment of the evolution of all credit variables should continue.the possible effects of narrower international financial conditions on the long-term real interest rate With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: china continues slowing down moderately; as for latin america, gdp growth in chile, mexico and peru was low and similar to that observed in recent quarters.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{banrep}{eight} Inflation, Employment, Growth, Peso Value Change, Trade, BanRep Interest Rate, Energy, and Climate.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: How much inflation is present in the Colombian Economy, measured by CPI, and whether or not this value increases.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: The rate of unemployment in Colombia and its change over time.\n    \\item \\emph{Growth}: The rate of GDP growth in Colombia's economy, and any changes to its value.\n    \\item \\emph{Peso Value Change}: The appreciation, depreciation, or maintenance of the Colombian Peso.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: The amount of imports and exports going in, and any changes in the amounts and distribution of these goods.\n    \\item \\emph{BanRep Interest Rate}: The current interest rate set by the Central Bank of Colombia and any decisions surrounding it.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy}: The availability and price of energy in Colombia\n    \\item \\emph{Climate}: Notable climate conditions impacting Colombia, such as El Ni\\~no.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``They noted that the concern of a significant impact on food or power costs by the El Ni\\~no phenomenon has been waning.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Poor climate conditions like El Ni\\~no put inflationary pressures on agricultural and energy sectors. With these effects improving, there is less inflation and more room to cut rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``They cautioned against sudden and unexpected interest rate cuts, which could fuel inflation expectations and currency depreciation, potentially jeopardizing the approximation to the inflation target and necessitating reversals with significant credibility costs.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BanRep committee members state their hesitancy toward cutting rates, indicating a hawkish outlook.\n    \n    \\item ``In the case of electricity rates, they emphasize that the risk of power outages has dissipated as hydro generation has been increasing and new solar plants are coming online.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Better power infrastructure is less likely to put inflationary pressures on energy prices, reducing the need to increase rates.\n\n    \\item ``This trend persists because essential items like rents, education, and personal services, among others, tend to adjust in line with observed inflation and wage increments.'' \\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: Makes a neutral remark regarding observed trends surrounding inflation, but does not provide a reason to either cut or raise rates.\n\n    \\item ``A regular meeting of the board of directors of Banco de la Republica was held in the city of Bogota on may 23, 2008.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence is a statement about an administrative meeting and does not contain any monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of the Republic}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Inflation} & When inflation is declining or is below the 3\\% target. & When inflation is rising or is above the 3\\% target. & When inflation is close to the target and unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Low/decreasing employment, deterioration of job quality, or sectors lobbying for rate cuts to improve the labor market. & High/increasing employment or improvements in the labor market. & Stable unemployment rates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Economic Growth} & When economic growth is currently low or expected to be low in the future. & When economic growth is currently too high to be sustainable, or expected to be as such. & When economic growth is stable without causing economic overheating. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Peso Value Change} & When the Peso appreciates. & When the Peso depreciates. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & More exports or fewer imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & Less exports or more imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BanRep Interest Rate} & When BanRep decides to or is planning on lowering the interest rate. & When BanRep decides to or is planning on raising the interest rate. & When BanRep leaves interest rate unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy} & Falling energy prices, higher energy availability. & Rising energy prices, lower energy availability. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Climate} & When climate in the region improves, reducing agricultural risks leading to inflation (for examples, food supply and prices). & When poor climate and weather conditions increase food prices or reduce agricultural output, leading to inflation. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Investment} & Lower levels of investment or delays in investment. & Higher levels of investment. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Security Prices} & Higher prices of public debt. & Lower prices of public debt. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Credit} & Decrease in credit or low levels of credit growth. & When credit growth is high. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:banrep_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: a regular meeting of the board of directors of banco de la república was held in the city of bogotá on may 23, 2008.\n                "}]
